pullRequest.title: Add strategy that optimize mixed index lookup followed by count step
pullRequest.bodyText:
This adds JanusGraphMixedIndexCountStrategy which leverages mixed index
to return the total count if applicable. The implementation idea is to
leverage the partial result of JanusGraphStepStrategy and JanusGraphStep
which handle folding and building a global graph centric query.
Closes #874

nodes.bodyText: Now I think constructing a direct index query might be the wrong direction. Using existing Stream<String> query(IndexQuery query, KeyInformation.IndexRetriever information, BaseTransaction tx) in IndexProvider and appending count seems better.

nodes.bodyText: You could maybe add some cases in which the query cannot be optimized and check that there is indeed no JanusGraphMixedIndexCountStep inserted. For example if there is an index but it's type is not mixed. Or there are steps between has(...) and count(), just to name a few ideas.
I like the Idea that the step itself performs the time consuming task of index selection, which makes it possible to track the work done in the optimization phase. Great idea!

It took me about half an hour to figure out that this is actually the line that checks if the optimization should be applied at all. I tried to find the line that clearly differentiates between mixed and composite indexes. The fact that this is buried deeply inside the index selection part is a bit of an obfuscation of what actually happens here.
Now that it became clear to me, it would be good to at least point out exactly what happens here.

These instanceof chains are used quite often so it would be better to move the check to a separate method. This would also give these steps a name that is more readable. For example while (isEligibleToSkip(currentStep)) {...}

I was thinking about more test cases. Can we add 2 more test cases?
has("nonIndexedProperty").has("indexedProperty").count()
has("indexedProperty").has("nonIndexedProperty").count()
What do you think about it? Maybe we already checking these cases in other tests. If so, just ignore this comment
the above 2 queries are computed the same but they should not be optimized with Mixed Query Count optimization because the whole chain of 'has' steps cannot be answered by a single mixed index.

nodes.bodyText: What is the reason to change these queries from count().next() to toList().size()? I see that the result should be equivalent, but therefore I don't see the necessity to change the query.

I stumbled upon this logic and was wondering if it is correct. For example, a query with count().count() (which by the way is completely bonkers) should always return 1, but would be reduced to one JanusGraphMixedIndexCountStep here.
@rngcntr This covers the case "tests combining mixed and composite indexes". "age" is indexed by a composite index while "name" is indexed by a mixed index.

nodes.bodyText:
I don't think this would be the expected behavior for chained V() calls. Instead, V() should spawn a new traverser at every single vertex for each incoming traverser. Thus, for a graph with 100 vertices, g.V().V().count() would return 10.000. With this test however, you seem to verify that the result is 100.
I suggest to test the correctness by comparing the result of g.[...] to g.withoutStrategies(JanusGraphMixedIndexCountStrategy.class).[...]. That would make sure that under no circumstances the optimization affects the output result. In my opinion, this should even be a considered standard procedure when introducing new optimization strategies. (Not blaming you, I skipped this kind of verification for some of my optimization strategies, too)
